question.title: [Metaculus] Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democra...nomination for President?
question.body:
Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden announcing he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President before July 15, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Incumbent advantage: Historically, sitting presidents rarely decline to run for a second term unless facing significant health issues or extreme unpopularity. Biden is the incumbent, which gives him a strong position within the party. 2. Age and health concerns: Biden will be 81 at the time of the 2024 election, making him the oldest president in U.S. history. There are ongoing concerns about his age and cognitive abilities, which could potentially lead to a decision not to run. 3. Current intentions: As of now (early 2024), Biden has repeatedly stated his intention to run for re-election and has not shown any signs of changing this stance. 4. Party support: The Democratic Party leadership has largely rallied behind Biden, and there is no strong push from within the party for him to step aside. 5. Polling and approval ratings: While Biden's approval ratings have been relatively low, they are not at a level that would typically force an incumbent out of the race. 6. Lack of strong alternatives: There is no clear frontrunner within the Democratic Party who could easily step in if Biden were to withdraw. 7. Time frame: The question asks about an announcement before July 15, 2024, which is relatively close to the Democratic National Convention (typically held in August). It's unlikely that a sitting president would wait until so late in the process to announce they're not running. 8. Political climate: The polarized nature of current U.S. politics makes it less likely for an incumbent to step aside, as it might be seen as ceding ground to the opposition. Given these factors, it seems unlikely that Biden will announce he's not accepting the nomination before July 15, 2024. While his age and some concerns about his performance are notable, the combination of incumbent advantage, lack of strong alternatives, and his current stated intentions make it improbable that he will bow out of the race.

question.title: Will the Republican Party retain Ohio's 6th congressional district (previously held by Bill Johnson) in the 2024 special election?
question.body: This question will resolve as Yes if credible sources report that a person representing the Republican Party has won the special election for OH's 6th district. If popular sources are in disagreement, an Ohio State source or statement will be used. If no election is held before January 1, 2025, the question is annulled.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of the Republican Party retaining Ohio's 6th congressional district in the 2024 special election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Historical voting patterns: Ohio's 6th district has been a Republican stronghold for many years. Bill Johnson, a Republican, held this seat from 2011 until his recent resignation to become president of Youngstown State University. 2. District demographics: The 6th district covers a large rural area in eastern Ohio, which typically leans conservative and has supported Republican candidates in recent elections. 3. 2022 election results: In the 2022 midterm elections, Bill Johnson won re-election with 67.4% of the vote, indicating strong Republican support in the district. 4. National political climate: While national trends can influence local elections, this district has remained solidly Republican even during years when Democrats performed well nationally. 5. Candidate quality: The strength of the candidates fielded by both parties can impact the outcome. However, given the district's strong Republican lean, even a relatively weak Republican candidate would likely have an advantage over a strong Democratic opponent. 6. Timing of the special election: Special elections can sometimes produce surprising results due to lower turnout or unique circumstances. However, the strong Republican base in this district makes an upset less likely. 7. Ohio's overall political landscape: Ohio has been trending more Republican in recent years, which could further reinforce the GOP's hold on this district. 8. Lack of significant demographic shifts: There's no indication of major population changes or redistricting that might alter the political composition of the district since the last election. Given these factors, especially the district's consistent Republican voting history, the large margin of victory in recent elections, and the overall political landscape of Ohio, it seems highly likely that the Republican Party will retain this seat in the special election.

metadata.chain_of_thought: This question requires both conditions to be met for a YES resolution, so we need to consider the probability of each event occurring and then multiply those probabilities. question.title: Will either Joe Biden announce he will not accept the Democratic nomination for President before July 15, 2024, or the Republican Party retain Ohio's 6th congressional district in the 2024 special election?
question.body:
(a) Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President? This resolves as Yes if, prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement that he will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. The statement must be unambiguous and conclusive, leaving no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President in the 2024 election cycle.

(b) Will the Republican Party retain Ohio's 6th congressional district in the 2024 special election? This resolves as Yes if credible sources report that a person representing the Republican Party has won the special election for OH's 6th district. If popular sources are in disagreement, an Ohio State source or statement will be used. If no election is held before January 1, 2025, the question is annulled.

The question resolves as Yes if either (a) or (b) occurs.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider both parts (a) and (b) separately, and then combine their probabilities. (a) Joe Biden announcing he will not accept the Democratic nomination: Currently, Joe Biden is the incumbent president and has already announced his intention to run for re-election in 2024. While there have been concerns about his age and some calls for a younger candidate, Biden and his team have consistently reaffirmed his commitment to running. It would be highly unusual and politically disruptive for an incumbent president to withdraw from the race, especially this late in the election cycle. The deadline given (July 15, 2024) is very close to the Democratic National Convention, which is typically held in August. At this point, most of the primary process would be complete. The probability of Biden withdrawing is very low, perhaps around 5%. (b) Republican Party retaining Ohio's 6th congressional district: Ohio's 6th district has been a Republican stronghold for many years. In the 2022 election, Republican Bill Johnson won with 67.4% of the vote. The district is largely rural and has consistently voted Republican in recent elections. While special elections can sometimes produce surprising results, the strong Republican lean of this district makes it highly likely that they will retain the seat. I would estimate the probability of the Republicans retaining this seat at around 90%. To calculate the overall probability, we need to consider that either of these events happening would result in a 'Yes' resolution. The probability of at least one of two independent events occurring is calculated by subtracting the probability of neither event occurring from 1: P(A or B) = 1 - P(not A and not B) = 1 - (1-P(A)) * (1-P(B)). Using our estimates: P(A) = 0.05 (Biden withdrawing), P(B) = 0.90 (Republicans retaining OH-6). 1 - (1-0.05) * (1-0.90) = 1 - 0.95 * 0.10 = 1 - 0.095 = 0.905. Therefore, the overall probability of this question resolving as 'Yes' is approximately 0.905 or 90.5%.

question.title: Will Vivek Ramaswamy be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Vivek Ramaswamy is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Vivek Ramaswamy becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current standing: As of now, Vivek Ramaswamy is a relatively new face in national politics. He has gained some attention for his conservative views and business background, but he lacks the political experience and name recognition of many other potential candidates. 2. Competition: The Republican field is likely to be crowded with more established politicians. Figures like Donald Trump, Ron DeSantis, Mike Pence, and Nikki Haley have much higher national profiles and stronger bases of support within the party. 3. Fundraising: While Ramaswamy has personal wealth, he may struggle to match the fundraising capabilities of more established candidates who have extensive donor networks. 4. Policy positions: Ramaswamy's views align with many conservative principles, which could appeal to the Republican base. However, his lack of political experience may raise questions about his ability to implement these ideas effectively. 5. Media attention: He has received some media coverage, but it's significantly less than that of front-runners like Trump or DeSantis. 6. Party establishment support: As a political outsider, Ramaswamy may struggle to gain support from the Republican party establishment, which often plays a crucial role in the nomination process. 7. Time until convention: With the convention still over a year away, there is time for Ramaswamy to build his profile and support. However, this also gives time for other candidates to consolidate their positions. 8. Historical precedent: It's rare for a political newcomer with no prior elected office to secure a major party nomination, though not impossible (as demonstrated by Trump in 2016). Given these factors, while it's not impossible for Ramaswamy to secure the nomination, it appears highly unlikely. He faces significant challenges in terms of name recognition, political experience, and party support compared to other potential candidates.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Rishi Sunak failing to be elected in the 2024 UK General Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Incumbent advantage: Rishi Sunak is the current Prime Minister and leader of the Conservative Party. Incumbent MPs, especially party leaders, typically have a strong advantage in their constituencies. 2. Constituency safety: Sunak represents Richmond (Yorks), which is considered a safe Conservative seat. In the 2019 election, he won with 63.6% of the vote, a very comfortable majority. 3. Personal popularity: While Sunak's popularity as Prime Minister has fluctuated, he remains relatively popular in his own constituency. 4. Party performance: The Conservative Party's overall performance in polls has been poor, trailing behind Labour. However, this is less likely to affect safe seats like Sunak's. 5. Historical precedent: It is extremely rare for a sitting Prime Minister to lose their seat in a general election. The last time this happened was in 1906 to Arthur Balfour. 6. Potential for tactical voting: In some constituencies, tactical voting against the Conservatives has been successful, but this is less likely in a safe seat with a high-profile incumbent. 7. Unforeseen circumstances: There's always a small chance of unexpected events (e.g., a major scandal) that could dramatically affect Sunak's chances, but this is unlikely. Given these factors, it seems highly improbable that Rishi Sunak would fail to be elected in his constituency. The combination of his incumbent advantage, the safety of his seat, and the historical rarity of a Prime Minister losing their seat makes it very likely he will be re-elected.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider both parts separately and then combine their probabilities. Part A: Vivek Ramaswamy being the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. Vivek Ramaswamy is a relatively new face in Republican politics. While he has gained some attention and support, he is still considered a long-shot candidate compared to more established figures like Donald Trump, Ron DeSantis, or Nikki Haley. Given the current political landscape and the strength of other candidates, the probability of Ramaswamy securing the Republican nomination is very low, perhaps around 1-2%. Part B: Rishi Sunak failing to be elected in the 2024 UK General Election. Rishi Sunak is the current Prime Minister of the UK and leader of the Conservative Party. Combining the probabilities: For this question to resolve as YES, either of these unlikely events needs to occur. Using the upper bounds of our estimates and applying the principle of addition for independent events: P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B) ≈ 0.02 + 0.10 - (0.02 * 0.10) ≈ 0.12 or 12%. This calculation assumes independence between the two events, which is a reasonable assumption given they are political events in different countries.

question.title: Will the European Union announce new tariffs or duties on imports of Chinese electric vehicles before July 5, 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if, before July 5, 2024, credible sources report that the European Union (EU) has announced that new tariffs or duties will be imposed that would apply to imports of Chinese electric vehicles into the EU.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this event occurring, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current trade tensions: There have been ongoing discussions and concerns within the EU about the influx of Chinese electric vehicles (EVs) into the European market. The EU has been worried about unfair competition due to potential Chinese state subsidies. 2. Recent investigations: In September 2023, the European Commission launched an anti-subsidy investigation into Chinese EVs, which is set to conclude by November 2024. This investigation could potentially lead to new tariffs or duties. 3. Timeframe: The question asks about an announcement before July 5, 2024, which is about 7.5 months from now. This is a relatively short timeframe for such a significant trade decision, especially considering that the investigation is not set to conclude until after this date. 4. Political pressure: There is increasing pressure from European automakers and some EU member states to protect the domestic EV industry from Chinese competition. 5. Potential retaliation: The EU must consider the risk of retaliation from China, which could impact other sectors of EU-China trade. 6. Global economic conditions: The current economic climate and any changes in the coming months could influence the EU's decision on whether to impose new tariffs. 7. Climate goals: The EU has ambitious climate targets, and imposing tariffs on EVs could potentially slow down EV adoption, which might factor into their decision-making process. Given these factors, I believe there is a moderate chance that the EU will announce new tariffs or duties on Chinese EVs before July 5, 2024. The ongoing investigation and political pressure suggest movement in this direction. However, the relatively short timeframe, the fact that the investigation is set to conclude after the given date, and the potential economic and diplomatic consequences of such a move make it far from certain.

question.title: Will a group of at least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
question.body:
Politico reports:

Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out. Two of the most endangered Democrats told local news outlets they’ve already written off Biden’s chances to win in November.

Behind the scenes, things are even more frenzied. There are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign, according to five people familiar with the efforts.

This market resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time).

This could be by signing a letter like what is reported above, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out.

This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution.

Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO. 

If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this event occurring, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political climate: There's growing concern among Democrats about Biden's age and electability, as evidenced by the Politico report mentioned. 2. Existing dissent: Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden to drop out, and two endangered Democrats have expressed pessimism about his chances. 3. Behind-the-scenes activity: Multiple drafts of letters are reportedly circulating among House Democrats, with at least one calling for Biden to end his campaign. 4. Time frame: The question asks about this happening before July 20th, which is about two months from now. This provides a significant window for dissent to grow and organize. 5. Electoral concerns: As the election approaches, Democrats may become increasingly worried about their chances of winning with Biden as the nominee, especially if polls show him trailing. 6. Precedent: It's unusual for a sitting president to be pressured to drop out by members of their own party, which could make some Democrats hesitant to take such a bold step. 7. Party unity: There's a risk that such a move could be seen as divisive and potentially harm the party's chances in the general election. 8. Biden's response: If Biden shows no signs of considering stepping down, it might embolden more Democrats to join the call for him to drop out. Given these factors, I believe there's a significant chance of this occurring, but it's far from certain. The existence of draft letters and the growing concerns among Democrats suggest that momentum is building. However, the requirement for at least five named individuals to act together publicly is a high bar, and many might be hesitant to take such a drastic step against a sitting president of their own party.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider both parts (a) and (b) separately and then combine their probabilities. (a) EU announces new tariffs or duties on Chinese electric vehicles before July 5, 2024: The EU has been increasingly concerned about the influx of cheaper Chinese electric vehicles (EVs) into the European market. There have been discussions about potential protective measures to support European automakers. However, implementing new tariffs is a significant step that requires careful consideration and usually takes time. Given the current economic climate and the EU's push for green technology, they might be hesitant to impose tariffs that could increase EV prices for consumers. For this to happen, there would need to be a significant event or revelation that dramatically changes the political landscape. Even then, most Democrats would likely see supporting the incumbent as their best chance for maintaining the presidency. Given these factors, I'd estimate the probability of this occurring at around 0.05. Combined probability: For both events to occur, we need to multiply their individual probabilities: 0.4 * 0.05 = 0.02.

(b) At least 5 named Democratic House Members or Senators pressuring Biden to drop out before July 20, 2024: This scenario is less likely. Despite concerns about Biden's age and some polls showing low approval ratings, the Democratic Party has largely rallied behind Biden for the 2024 election. There's a strong tradition in U.S. politics of supporting the incumbent president for re-election. However, if Biden's poll numbers were to significantly worsen or if there were a major gaffe or health concern, some Democrats might consider asking him to step aside. But for five or more to do so publicly and collectively would be extraordinary and potentially damaging to the party. I'd estimate the probability of this occurring at around 15%. Combining these probabilities: The probability of at least one of these events occurring is the complement of the probability that neither occurs. P(at least one occurs) = 1 - P(neither occurs) = 1 - [(1 - 0.40) * (1 - 0.15)] = 1 - (0.60 * 0.85) = 1 - 0.51 = 0.49. Therefore, I estimate a 49% chance of this question resolving YES.

question.title: Will Greece qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if Greece participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. If Greece does not qualify, the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Greece qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Historical performance: Greece has a strong track record in Eurovision. Since the introduction of semi-finals in 2004, Greece has qualified for the Grand Final in 16 out of 19 attempts. This gives them an 84% success rate in qualifying. 2. Recent performance: In the last five years (2019-2023), Greece has qualified for the Grand Final four times, missing out only in 2019. This shows a consistent recent performance. 3. Quality of entries: Greece typically sends entries that are well-received by both juries and televoting audiences. They often feature a mix of traditional Greek sounds with modern pop elements, which tends to appeal to a wide audience. 4. Diaspora voting: Greece benefits from diaspora voting, particularly from Cyprus and other countries with significant Greek populations. This often provides a boost in televoting scores. 5. Staging and performance: Greece usually invests in strong staging and performances, which can help their entries stand out in the semi-finals. 6. Competition level: The level of competition in the semi-finals can vary from year to year, but Greece's consistent qualification suggests they can handle most levels of competition. 7. Semi-final allocation: The specific semi-final Greece is allocated to can affect their chances, but this information is not available at the time of this assessment. 8. Potential changes: While we don't have information about Greece's 2024 entry yet, there's no reason to believe they will significantly deviate from their usual approach to Eurovision. Given Greece's strong historical performance, recent success, and various advantages in the competition, it seems highly likely that they will qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024. However, there's always an element of uncertainty in Eurovision, and surprises can happen.

Given Lithuania's recent strong qualification record, their consistent selection process, and their ability to send diverse and appealing entries, I believe they have a good chance of qualifying for the Grand Final in 2024. question.title: Will both Greece and Lithuania qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met: (1) Greece participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final; (2) Lithuania participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of both Greece and Lithuania qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Given these factors, Greece has a historically high chance of qualifying, while Lithuania has been showing improvement in recent years. If we assume Greece has about an 80% chance (slightly lower than historical average due to recent fluctuation) and Lithuania has about a 70% chance (higher than historical average due to recent success), the probability of both qualifying would be: 0.80 * 0.70 = 0.56 or 56%. question.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:
This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024.

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of Trump's lead over Biden being greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current polling trends: As of July 5, 2024, Trump is leading Biden by 2.4 points. This is within the range specified in the question, which suggests that the scenario is plausible. 2. Time frame: The resolution date is only 10 days after the current polling data. In such a short period, dramatic shifts in polling are less likely unless there's a major event. 3. Historical volatility: Presidential polls tend to fluctuate, but often within a relatively narrow range, especially as the election approaches. 4. Margin of error: Most polls have a margin of error of around 3 percentage points, which means small changes are common and expected. 5. Potential events: While we can't predict specific events, we should consider that any significant news or developments could impact the polls in either direction. 6. Regression to the mean: If the current 2.4-point lead is seen as unusually high, there might be a slight tendency for it to decrease towards a long-term average. 7. Precision of the range: The specified range (>2 and ≤3) is quite narrow, which makes it less likely to occur compared to a broader range. Given these factors, I believe there's a reasonable chance that Trump's lead will remain within the specified range. The current lead is already within this range, and major shifts are less likely in a short timeframe. However, the narrowness of the range and the potential for small fluctuations or unexpected events make it far from certain.

question.title: Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a **Yes** resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden announcing he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President before July 15, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Incumbency advantage: Historically, incumbent presidents rarely decline to seek re-election unless faced with significant challenges or health issues. Biden is the incumbent, which typically favors running for a second term. 2. Current intentions: As of now (July 2024), Biden has repeatedly stated his intention to run for re-election and has not given any strong indications of changing his mind. 3. Age and health concerns: Biden will be 81 at the start of a potential second term, making him the oldest president in U.S. history. This has raised concerns about his ability to serve effectively for another four years. However, he has maintained that he is fit for office. 4. Party support: The Democratic Party leadership has generally rallied behind Biden's re-election bid, and there is no significant primary challenge at this point. 5. Timing: With the question resolving on July 15, 2024, we are very close to the Democratic National Convention (typically held in August). It would be highly unusual and potentially damaging to the party for a sitting president to withdraw so late in the process. 6. Political landscape: While Biden's approval ratings have fluctuated, there's no overwhelming crisis or scandal that would likely force him to step aside at this late stage. 7. Lack of clear alternative: The Democratic Party has not groomed an obvious successor, which makes it less likely for Biden to step aside without a clear replacement. Given these factors, it seems highly unlikely that Biden would announce he will not accept the nomination at this late stage. The only scenarios where this might occur would be a sudden, severe health issue or an unforeseen major political crisis, both of which are relatively low-probability events.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average, and (2) Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?
question.body:
(1) Trump's lead over Biden will be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average. This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024. For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

(2) Joe Biden will announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President. This question will resolve as **Yes** if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. To qualify for a **Yes** resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle. If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider the likelihood of both conditions occurring simultaneously. Let's break it down: 1. Trump's lead over Biden being greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024: This is a very specific range for Trump's lead. While current polls show Trump with a slight lead, predicting such a precise margin over a year in advance is challenging. Polls can fluctuate significantly, and many factors can influence them between now and July 2024. The probability of hitting this exact range is relatively low, perhaps around 15-20%. 2. Joe Biden announcing before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination: This is highly unlikely. Biden has consistently expressed his intention to run for re-election and has already launched his 2024 campaign. While there have been concerns about his age and some calls for him to step aside, he and his team have repeatedly reaffirmed his commitment to running. For Biden to reverse course and decline the nomination would be a major political shock. The probability of this happening is very low, perhaps around 5-10%. For both of these events to occur simultaneously, we need to multiply their individual probabilities. Even if we take the higher estimates for each event (20% for the polling condition and 10% for Biden's withdrawal), the combined probability would be 0.20 * 0.10 = 0.02 or 2%. However, it's worth noting that these events are not entirely independent. If Biden were to announce he's not accepting the nomination, it could potentially affect Trump's polling numbers. But given the extreme unlikelihood of Biden making such an announcement, this consideration doesn't significantly alter the overall probability.

question.title: Will either Trump's lead over Biden be between 2 and 3 points on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average, or will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if either of the following occurs:

(a) Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's national polling average for the 2024 presidential election is greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, as reported on the chart when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024. A positive value means a Trump lead.

(b) Prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement that he will not seek and will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President in the 2024 cycle. The statement must be unambiguous and conclusive, leaving no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the nomination.

If neither (a) nor (b) occurs, this question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this question resolving as YES, we need to consider both conditions separately and then combine their likelihoods. a) Trump's lead over Biden between 2 and 3 points on July 15, 2024: As of now (July 2023), it's still early to predict polling averages for July 2024 with high certainty. However, recent polls have shown a close race between Trump and Biden, with some polls giving Trump a slight lead. The specific range of 2-3 points is quite narrow, which makes it less likely to occur. Given the volatility of polls and the time left until the specified date, I'd estimate the probability of this specific condition being met at around 10-15%. b) Biden announcing he won't accept the Democratic nomination before July 15, 2024: As of now, Joe Biden has announced his intention to run for re-election and has not given any indication that he plans to step aside. While there have been concerns about his age and some calls for a younger candidate, Biden and his team have consistently reaffirmed his commitment to running. For Biden to make such an announcement, there would likely need to be a significant change in circumstances, such as a major health issue or a dramatic shift in public opinion. The probability of this happening seems low, perhaps around 5-10%. Combining these probabilities: The question resolves as YES if either of these events occurs. Using the formula for the probability of either of two independent events occurring (P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B)), and using the higher end of our estimates: P(YES) = 0.15 + 0.10 - (0.15 * 0.10) = 0.235. This calculation assumes the events are independent, which is a reasonable assumption given their nature.

question.title: Will a member of the Trump family be the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024?
question.body:

 - Donald Trump Jr.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of a Trump family member becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Donald Trump's influence: Despite his controversial presidency and two impeachments, Donald Trump maintains significant support within the Republican Party. He has hinted at running again in 2024 and remains a popular figure among the GOP base. 2. Other Trump family members: While Donald Trump is the most likely family member to run, other family members like Donald Trump Jr. and Ivanka Trump have shown political ambitions. However, they lack the same level of experience and support as their father. 3. Current political landscape: The Republican Party is somewhat divided between Trump loyalists and those seeking to move away from his influence. This division could impact the nomination process. 4. Potential challengers: Several other prominent Republicans, such as Ron DeSantis, Mike Pence, and Nikki Haley, have been positioning themselves for a potential 2024 run. These candidates could pose significant competition to any Trump family member. 5. Time until the nomination: With the nomination still over a year away, there's ample time for the political landscape to shift, potentially affecting a Trump family member's chances. 6. Legal challenges: Donald Trump faces several ongoing legal investigations, which could potentially impact his ability to run or his popularity among voters. 7. Historical precedent: It's rare for a former president to run again after losing re-election, though not unprecedented (Grover Cleveland did so successfully). Given these factors, I believe there is a significant chance that a Trump family member, most likely Donald Trump himself, will be the Republican nominee. However, it's far from certain due to the potential challenges and competition.

question.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Joe Biden announces before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President, (b) A member of the Trump family is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024?
question.body:

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this question resolving as YES, we need to consider both parts separately and then combine their likelihoods. (a) Joe Biden announcing he won't accept the Democratic nomination: As of now (2023), Joe Biden has announced his intention to run for re-election in 2024. He is the incumbent president and has the support of the Democratic Party leadership. However, there are concerns about his age (he would be 82 at the start of a second term) and his approval ratings have been relatively low. Using the formula for the probability of either of two events occurring (P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B)), and assuming the events are independent: P(YES) = P(Biden withdraws) + P(Trump family nominee) - P(Both occur) ≈ 0.15 + 0.70 - (0.15 * 0.70) ≈ 0.85 - 0.105 ≈ 0.745. This calculation suggests a high probability of the question resolving as YES, primarily driven by the likelihood of Donald Trump becoming the Republican nominee.

question.title: Will Biden remain President through end of July 2024?
question.body:
Resolves YES if Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET); resolves NO if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then.

Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendement (i.e. making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution. (Acting President is different from President under the Constitution)

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden remaining President through the end of July 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current health and age: Biden is currently 80 years old (born November 20, 1942). While he has maintained relatively good health, his advanced age does increase the risk of health issues. 2. Historical precedent: No U.S. President has died in office since John F. Kennedy in 1963, and no President has resigned since Richard Nixon in 1974. This suggests a low probability of either event occurring. 3. Political stability: There are no significant indications of a potential resignation. Biden has expressed his intention to run for re-election in 2024, which suggests he plans to complete his current term. 4. Constitutional safeguards: The 25th Amendment allows for temporary transfer of power without causing a change in presidency, which reduces the likelihood of a permanent transfer due to temporary health issues. 5. Time frame: The question asks about a period ending in July 2024, which is about 10 months from now. This relatively short time frame reduces the likelihood of unforeseen events causing Biden to leave office. 6. Biden's cognitive abilities: While there have been concerns about Biden's mental acuity, these have not significantly impacted his ability to perform his duties as President so far. 7. Support system: Biden has a strong support system in place, including medical staff and advisors, which helps mitigate risks associated with his age and health. Given these factors, the probability of Biden remaining President through the end of July 2024 is quite high. While there are always unforeseen risks, especially given his age, the historical precedent, current political stability, and constitutional safeguards all point towards a high likelihood of him completing this portion of his term.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: This is a complex question that requires careful consideration of several factors: 1. Legal precedent: There have been attempts to use Section 3 of the 14th Amendment to disqualify candidates before, but they have rarely been successful. The most notable recent case was the attempt to remove Marjorie Taylor Greene from the ballot in Georgia, which failed. 2. Current legal challenges: As of now, there are ongoing efforts in several states to remove Trump from the ballot using the 14th Amendment. The most prominent cases are in Colorado and Minnesota, where lawsuits have been filed. 3. Time frame: The resolution date is July 15, 2024, which gives ample time for legal challenges to progress through the court system, potentially reaching the Supreme Court. 4. Political climate: The use of the 14th Amendment to disqualify Trump is highly controversial and politically charged. It's likely to face significant opposition from Republican-controlled state governments and Trump supporters. 5. Supreme Court involvement: Given the high-stakes nature of this issue, it's likely that any successful attempt to remove Trump from a ballot would be quickly appealed to the Supreme Court. The current conservative majority on the Court might be skeptical of such an interpretation of the 14th Amendment. 6. State-by-state variation: Different states may interpret and apply the 14th Amendment differently, increasing the chances that at least one state might remove Trump from the ballot. 7. Trump's legal troubles: Trump is facing multiple criminal indictments, which could potentially strengthen arguments for his disqualification under the 14th Amendment. Given these factors, I believe there is a non-trivial chance that Trump could be removed from at least one state's ballot by July 15, 2024. The ongoing legal challenges and the length of time until the resolution date increase this possibility. However, the political and legal hurdles remain significant, and the conservative Supreme Court could ultimately block such efforts. Considering all these factors, I estimate the probability of this occurring to be moderate but still less than 50%.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Biden remains President through the end of July 2024 and (b) Donald Trump is removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
(a) Resolves YES if Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET); resolves NO if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then. Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment (i.e. making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution. (Acting President is different from President under the Constitution).

(b) This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024. Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider both parts (a) and (b) separately and then combine their probabilities. (a) Biden remaining President through the end of July 2024: Joe Biden is currently 80 years old and will be 81 by July 2024. While his age is a factor, he has not shown any severe health issues that would suggest he's likely to resign or be unable to continue his duties. The probability of an average 81-year-old man dying within a year is relatively low (around 5-6%). Additionally, there are no strong indications of Biden planning to resign. Therefore, the probability of Biden remaining President through July 2024 is quite high, perhaps around 0.90 to 0.95. (b) Donald Trump being removed or blocked from a primary ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment: This is a more complex and uncertain situation. Several factors to consider: 1. There have been discussions and some legal attempts to use the 14th Amendment to disqualify Trump from running, based on his alleged role in the January 6th Capitol riot. 2. As of now, no state has successfully removed Trump from the ballot on these grounds. 3. The legal interpretation of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment in this context is untested and controversial. 4. Any attempt to remove Trump from a ballot would likely face strong legal challenges and could be overturned. 5. The political implications of such a move are significant, which might make states hesitant to take this action. Given these factors, while it's possible that a state might attempt to remove Trump from the ballot, the likelihood of it being successfully implemented and maintained through July 15, 2024, seems relatively low. I would estimate this probability at around 0.20 to 0.30. For both (a) and (b) to occur, we need to multiply their individual probabilities. Using the middle of our estimated ranges: 0.925 (Biden remaining President) * 0.25 (Trump being removed from a ballot) = 0.23125.

metadata.chain_of_thought: This question has two parts, and if either part is true, the question resolves YES. Let's analyze each part: 1. Biden remaining President through July 2024: Joe Biden is currently the President of the United States and his term is set to end in January 2025. Barring any unforeseen circumstances, it is highly likely that he will remain President through July 2024. Presidents rarely leave office before their term ends, and there are no significant indications that Biden plans to resign or is facing any immediate health concerns that would prevent him from serving. The probability of this part being true is very high, perhaps around 95%. 2. Trump being removed from any primary election ballot under the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024: This is a more complex and uncertain situation. While there have been discussions and some legal attempts to use the 14th Amendment to disqualify Trump from running for office due to his alleged role in the January 6th Capitol riot, the success of such efforts is far from certain. As of now, no state has officially removed Trump from their primary ballot under these grounds. However, there are ongoing legal challenges and debates about this issue. Some states, like Colorado, have seen attempts to remove Trump from the ballot, but these have not been successful so far. The issue may eventually reach the Supreme Court for a definitive ruling. Given the controversial nature of this action and the potential for legal challenges, it seems unlikely that Trump will be successfully removed from all primary ballots by July 15, 2024. However, it's not impossible that at least one state might take this action. I would estimate the probability of this occurring at around 20%. Combining these two scenarios, we need to consider the probability of at least one of them occurring. Using the formula for the probability of at least one of two independent events occurring (P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B)), we get: 0.95 + 0.20 - (0.95 * 0.20) = 0.96. This means there's a 96% chance that at least one of these conditions will be met.

question.title: Will Liz Cheney be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Liz Cheney is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Liz Cheney becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political landscape: Liz Cheney has positioned herself as a strong critic of former President Donald Trump, which has alienated her from a significant portion of the Republican base that remains loyal to Trump. 2. Recent political history: Cheney was removed from her leadership position in the House Republican Conference in 2021 due to her criticism of Trump and her vote to impeach him. This indicates a lack of support from her party's establishment. 3. Polling data: Current polls for the 2024 Republican nomination show Cheney with very low support, often in the low single digits, far behind frontrunners like Trump and Florida Governor Ron DeSantis. 4. Fundraising and campaign infrastructure: While Cheney has been able to raise significant funds, much of this support comes from anti-Trump Republicans and even some Democrats, which may not translate to support in Republican primaries. 5. Republican party dynamics: The party has largely embraced Trump's policies and rhetoric, which is at odds with Cheney's more traditional conservative stance. 6. Time until the convention: While there is still time until the 2024 convention, it would require a massive shift in Republican voter sentiment for Cheney to become a frontrunner. 7. Potential for a third-party run: There has been speculation that Cheney might run as an independent or third-party candidate, which could further reduce her chances of securing the Republican nomination. Given these factors, it appears highly unlikely that Liz Cheney will be selected as the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. While unexpected events could potentially change the political landscape, based on the current information and trends, the probability of this outcome is very low.

Given these factors, especially the historical voting patterns, the demographics of the district, and the margin of victory in recent elections, it seems highly likely that the Republican Party will retain this seat in the special election. question.title: Will 538 Project Biden as the favorite on Friday?
question.body:
This market will resolve to “Yes” if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. This market will resolve to “No” if Donald Trump has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this market will resolve 50-50.

The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2024-election-forecast/, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market.

This market will resolve according to the datapoints for July 19 as soon as datapoints for July 20 become available. This market may not resolve until the July 20 datapoints are available. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, this market will resolve according to the nearest previous figures to July 19.

Please note the resolution refers to the odds of each candidate winning as a number out of 100 reported to the 1 digit mark (eg. "Trump 57 times out of 100"). The listed number of simulations out of 1,000 won by each candidate will NOT be considered.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current polling and forecasts: As of now (July 2023), Biden and Trump are the frontrunners for their respective parties, but the election is still over a year away. Current polls show a close race, with some giving Biden a slight edge and others favoring Trump. 2. FiveThirtyEight's methodology: FiveThirtyEight is known for its data-driven approach and tends to be more conservative in its predictions, especially this far out from the election. 3. Incumbent advantage: Biden is the incumbent president, which historically has provided an advantage, though this effect can vary. 4. Economic factors: The state of the economy in July 2024 will likely play a significant role in voter sentiment. 5. Potential unforeseen events: Major national or international events could significantly impact public opinion in the year leading up to the election. 6. Historical trends: Historically, presidential races tend to tighten as the election approaches. 7. FiveThirtyEight's past performance: In previous elections, FiveThirtyEight has often shown a close race, even when other forecasters were more decisive. Given these factors, I believe it's more likely than not that FiveThirtyEight will show Biden as a slight favorite by July 19, 2024. The incumbent advantage and the tendency for FiveThirtyEight to give weight to structural factors that favor incumbents support this view. However, the margin is likely to be narrow given the expected competitiveness of the race and FiveThirtyEight's typically cautious approach. It's important to note that this prediction comes with significant uncertainty due to the long time frame and the potential for major shifts in the political landscape.

He's a moderate Democrat with a strong background in science and the military. b) Josh Shapiro: The current Governor of Pennsylvania, a key swing state. He has a strong record as Attorney General and won his gubernatorial race decisively. 4. Historical precedent: In modern U.S. politics, it's extremely rare for an incumbent president to change their vice presidential running mate. Current administration dynamics: There have been no significant indications of a rift between President Biden and Vice President Harris that would necessitate a change in the ticket. 6. Media speculation: While there may be media speculation about potential VP picks, it's important to note that such speculation is often unreliable, especially when dealing with an incumbent administration. Given these factors, it seems highly improbable that Kamala Harris would be in a position to choose a new running mate for the 2024 election. The question appears to be based on a premise that is unlikely to occur - namely, that Harris would be selecting a running mate at all. The only scenario where this could happen is if there was a major, unexpected change in the current administration, such as President Biden deciding not to run for re-election and Harris becoming the presidential nominee. However, there are no credible indications of such a dramatic shift at this time. Therefore, the probability of the question resolving YES (Harris choosing either Kelly or Shapiro) is extremely low. The most likely outcome is that no VP selection will occur at all, which would result in a NO resolution.

Given these factors, it seems unlikely that the Olympic record will be broken in 2024. question.title: Will Kamala Harris be the Democratic VP?
question.body: If Kamala Harris is nominated as the Democratic VP, this market will resolve to yes. If someone else is selected as VP, this market will resolve to no. If the VP is changed for any reason after the initial nomination, that will not change the resolution of this market. The market can resolve immediately after the nomination.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Kamala Harris being the Democratic VP nominee for the 2024 election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Incumbency advantage: Kamala Harris is the current Vice President, and it's relatively rare for a sitting president to change their running mate when seeking re-election. This gives her a significant advantage. 2. Historical precedent: In modern U.S. politics, it's uncommon for an incumbent president to switch vice presidents unless there are extraordinary circumstances or significant conflicts. 3. Biden's commitment: President Joe Biden has repeatedly expressed his intention to run for re-election in 2024, and he has publicly praised Harris's work and contributions to his administration. 4. Democratic Party unity: Replacing Harris could potentially create discord within the Democratic Party, especially among key constituencies that Harris represents (women, people of color). 5. Harris's performance: While Harris has faced some criticism during her tenure, she has not been involved in any major scandals or controversies that would necessitate her replacement. 6. Time until nomination: The resolution date is set for August 10, 2024, which is likely around the time of the Democratic National Convention. This gives ample time for any potential changes, but also reinforces the likelihood of maintaining the status quo. 7. Lack of strong alternatives: There are no clear, standout alternatives to Harris that would provide a significant boost to the ticket without potentially alienating other parts of the Democratic base. However, we must also consider potential factors that could lead to a change: 1. Harris's approval ratings have been lower than Biden's at times, which could theoretically prompt a strategic change. 2. Unforeseen events or scandals could emerge that might necessitate a change, although this seems unlikely given the time Harris has already served without major issues. 3. Biden could decide not to run for re-election, which could open up the field for a new ticket entirely, though this scenario seems increasingly unlikely given his public statements. Considering all these factors, the probability of Kamala Harris being the Democratic VP nominee again is very high. While not absolutely certain, the combination of incumbency advantage, party unity considerations, and lack of compelling reasons for change make it highly likely that she will remain on the ticket.

question.title: Will Portugal qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if Portugal participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. If Portugal does not qualify, the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Portugal qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Historical performance: Portugal has participated in Eurovision since 1964 and has qualified for the Grand Final 11 times out of 21 attempts since the introduction of semi-finals in 2004. This gives them a qualification rate of about 52%. 2. Recent performance: Portugal qualified for the Grand Final in 2022 and 2023, showing a positive trend in their recent performances. 3. Quality of entries: Portugal has been sending generally well-received entries in recent years, with their 2017 entry even winning the contest. This suggests a commitment to quality performances. 4. Voting patterns: Portugal often receives support from Spanish-speaking countries and former colonies, which can help in the semi-finals. 5. Competition level: The overall quality of entries in Eurovision has been increasing, making qualification more challenging for all countries. 6. Draw position: The running order in the semi-final can affect qualification chances, but this information is not available yet for 2024. 7. Changes in format or voting system: Any potential changes to the Eurovision format or voting system for 2024 are unknown at this time, which could impact qualification chances. 8. Internal selection vs. national final: The method Portugal will use to choose their entry is unknown, which can affect the quality of the song and performer. Considering these factors, Portugal has a slightly better than average chance of qualifying. Their recent success in qualifying for the past two years and their overall qualification rate of 52% suggest a positive outlook. However, the increasing competition and unknown factors for 2024 prevent us from being overly confident.

question.title: On July 17, 2024, will Nvidia's market capitalization be larger than Apple's?
question.body: This question resolves Yes if, on July 17, 2024, the market cap of Nvidia is greater than that of Apple, according to Companies Market Cap, when checked by Metaculus at approximately 4 PM EDT (8 PM UTC).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider several factors: 1. Given these factors, while Nvidia has strong growth potential, overtaking Apple in market cap by July 2024 seems unlikely. The gap is currently too large to close in just a year under normal circumstances. question.title: Will a group of at least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
question.body:
Politico reports:

Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out. Two of the most endangered Democrats told local news outlets they’ve already written off Biden’s chances to win in November.

Behind the scenes, things are even more frenzied. There are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign, according to five people familiar with the efforts.

This market resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time).

This could be by signing a letter like what is reported above, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out.

This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution.

Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO. 

If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this event occurring, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political climate: There's growing concern among Democrats about Biden's age and electability. This is evidenced by the Politico report mentioning two safe-seat members publicly urging Biden to drop out and two endangered Democrats writing off his chances. 2. Existing efforts: The report mentions multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats, with at least one calling on Biden to end his campaign. This indicates that there's already momentum building towards this kind of action. 3. Time frame: We have about two weeks until the July 20th deadline. This is a relatively short period, but it's enough time for coordination to occur if there's sufficient motivation. 4. Pressure from polls and public opinion: If Biden's poll numbers continue to decline or public opinion shifts significantly against him, it could embolden more Democrats to take action. 5. Risk aversion: Many Democrats might be hesitant to publicly pressure the sitting president of their own party, fearing potential backlash or division within the party. 6. Alternatives: The likelihood of this happening may depend on whether Democrats see a viable alternative candidate who could step in. 7. Biden's response: If Biden shows any signs of considering stepping down, it might encourage more Democrats to join the effort. Given these factors, I believe there's a significant chance of this occurring, but it's not yet more likely than not. The existing efforts and growing concerns provide a foundation for this to happen, but the short time frame and potential hesitancy to publicly challenge the sitting president are significant obstacles.

question.title: Will a swimmer win the most gold medals at the 2024 Paris Olympics?
question.body: The question resolves as **Yes** if the athlete with the highest number of 2024 Olympic gold medals competes in the swimming events.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of a swimmer winning the most gold medals at the 2024 Paris Olympics, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current swimming stars: We need to consider the current swimming landscape. Caeleb Dressel (USA) won five gold medals in Tokyo 2020, showing the potential for swimmers to dominate. Other swimmers like Katie Ledecky (USA) and Adam Peaty (GBR) have also shown consistent excellence. 4. Competition from other sports: Track and field athletes, particularly sprinters and distance runners, can also win multiple medals. Gymnasts, especially in women's events, have the potential to win multiple golds as well. 5. Team sports: While team sport athletes can win gold, they typically only win one per Olympics, making it less likely for them to be the top gold medal winner. 6. Recent Olympic trends: In Tokyo 2020, swimmers Caeleb Dressel (5 golds) and Emma McKeon (4 golds) were among the top individual gold medal winners, reinforcing swimming's strong position. 7. Time until the Olympics: With the Olympics about a year away, current top performers are likely to maintain their form, barring injuries or unexpected setbacks. Given these factors, swimmers have a strong chance of winning the most gold medals. The multi-event nature of swimming, combined with the presence of dominant swimmers in recent Olympics, gives them an edge over athletes from other sports. However, it's not a certainty, as exceptional athletes from other sports could potentially match or exceed the top swimmers' medal counts.

There are eight women's team sports listed, and for this condition to be met, one nation would need to win at least two of them. The United States is often strong in basketball (both 3x3 and 5x5) and volleyball. Other nations like the Netherlands (field hockey) and Australia (rugby sevens) have strengths in specific sports. However, it's rare for a single nation to dominate across multiple team sports due to the high level of global competition. Combining these factors: The first condition (swimmer winning most golds) seems more likely than the second (same nation winning multiple team sports). However, we only need one of these conditions to be true for the question to resolve as Yes. Given the historical performance of swimmers in Olympics and the multiple opportunities they have for medals, I'd estimate there's about a 60% chance a swimmer will win the most gold medals. For the second condition, I'd estimate a lower probability of about 30% that one nation will win more than one women's team sport gold. The probability of at least one of these events occurring is the complement of the probability that neither occurs: 1 - (1 - 0.6) * (1 - 0.3) = 1 - 0.4 * 0.7 = 1 - 0.28 = 0.72. Therefore, I estimate a 72% chance that this question will resolve as Yes.

question.title: Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a **Yes** resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden announcing he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President before July 15, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Incumbency advantage: Historically, incumbent presidents rarely decline to seek re-election unless faced with significant challenges or health issues. Biden is the incumbent, which typically favors running for a second term. 2. Current intentions: As of now (July 2024), Biden has repeatedly stated his intention to run for re-election and has not shown any signs of changing this stance. 3. Age and health concerns: Biden will be 81 at the time of the 2024 election, making him the oldest president in U.S. history. While his health appears stable, concerns about his age could potentially influence his decision. 4. Party support: The Democratic Party leadership has generally rallied behind Biden, and there's no significant push from within the party for him to step aside. 5. Polling and approval ratings: While Biden's approval ratings have fluctuated, they haven't dropped to levels that would typically force an incumbent to reconsider running. 6. Time frame: The question's resolution date is very close to the Democratic National Convention (typically held in July or August). It's highly unlikely for a sitting president to announce they won't accept the nomination this late in the process, as it would throw the party into chaos. 7. Lack of strong alternatives: There isn't a clear successor or alternative candidate that the Democratic Party has been grooming, which makes it less likely for Biden to step aside. 8. Political climate: The political landscape and Biden's performance in office up to this point don't suggest any drastic changes that would prompt him to suddenly decline the nomination. Given these factors, it seems highly improbable that Biden would announce he won't accept the nomination, especially this close to the convention. While there's always a small chance of unexpected events or health issues arising, the likelihood of such an announcement is very low.

question.title: Will Kamala Harris be the Democratic VP?
question.body: If Kamala Harris is nominated as the Democratic VP, this market will resolve to yes. If someone else is selected as VP, this market will resolve to no. If the VP is changed for any reason after the initial nomination, that will not change the resolution of this market. The market can resolve immediately after the nomination.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Kamala Harris being the Democratic VP nominee for the 2024 election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Incumbency advantage: Kamala Harris is the current Vice President, and it's relatively rare for a sitting president to change their running mate when seeking re-election. This gives her a significant advantage. 2. Historical precedent: In modern U.S. politics, it's uncommon for a president to switch vice presidents between their first and second terms. The last time this happened was in 1976 when Gerald Ford replaced Nelson Rockefeller with Bob Dole. 3. Biden's commitment: President Joe Biden has repeatedly expressed his intention to run for re-election and has given no indication that he plans to replace Harris as his running mate. 4. Democratic Party unity: Changing the VP nominee could be seen as a sign of instability or lack of confidence in the administration, which the Democratic Party would likely want to avoid. 5. Harris's demographic appeal: As the first woman, first African American, and first Asian American to hold the office of Vice President, Harris brings important diversity to the ticket, which is valuable for the Democratic Party's base. 6. Timing: The resolution date is set for August 10, 2024, which is likely to be after the Democratic National Convention where the nomination would be officially confirmed. 7. Potential challenges: While Harris has faced some criticism and has had lower approval ratings than Biden at times, these issues don't seem severe enough to warrant replacing her on the ticket. 8. Limited alternatives: There doesn't appear to be any strong push for an alternative VP candidate within the Democratic Party. Given these factors, especially the strong historical precedent for keeping the incumbent VP and the lack of any significant indications that a change is being considered, it seems highly likely that Kamala Harris will be the Democratic VP nominee for the 2024 election.
