If neither Norway nor Switzerland qualifies, the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of either Norway or Switzerland qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Historical performance: Both Norway and Switzerland have had mixed results in recent years, but they've generally been competitive. - Norway has qualified for the Grand Final in 7 out of the last 10 contests (2013-2023, excluding 2020 which was cancelled). - Switzerland has qualified for the Grand Final in 5 out of the last 10 contests. 2. Recent success: - Norway finished 5th in the 2023 Grand Final with Alessandra's 'Queen of Kings.' - Switzerland didn't qualify for the 2023 Grand Final but finished 4th in 2021. 3. Eurovision voting patterns: Both countries have established voting blocs and cultural connections that can help them in the semi-finals. 4. Quality of entries: While we don't know the specific songs for 2024 yet, both countries have generally sent high-quality entries in recent years. 5. Semi-final allocation: The distribution of countries in each semi-final can affect qualification chances, but this is not known at the time of this assessment. 6. Combined chances: With two countries in question, the odds of at least one qualifying are higher than for a single country. Given these factors, the chances of either Norway or Switzerland qualifying are quite good. Norway's recent consistency in qualifying and Switzerland's potential to bounce back from a non-qualification suggest a high probability of at least one of them making it to the Grand Final. However, there's always an element of unpredictability in Eurovision, depending on the quality of other entries, voting patterns, and performance on the night. While it's not a certainty, the combined chances of these two countries make it more likely than not that at least one will qualify.

question.title: [Metaculus] Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democra...nomination for President?
question.body:
Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden announcing he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President before July 15, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current status: As of now (July 2023), Joe Biden has already announced his intention to run for re-election in 2024 and is actively campaigning. 2. Age factor: Biden will be 81 at the start of a potential second term, making him the oldest president in U.S. history. This has raised concerns about his ability to serve effectively for another four years. 3. Approval ratings: Biden's approval ratings have been relatively low, which could potentially influence his decision to continue his campaign. 4. Democratic Party support: Despite some concerns, the Democratic Party leadership has largely rallied behind Biden's re-election bid. 5. Precedent: It is extremely rare for an incumbent president to decide not to seek re-election, especially after already announcing their intention to run. 6. Time frame: The question asks about an announcement before July 15, 2024, which is very close to the Democratic National Convention (typically held in August). It's unlikely for a major party to be without a nominee so close to the convention. 7. Biden's commitment: Biden has consistently expressed his commitment to running for re-election and has given no indication of changing his mind. 8. Health considerations: While Biden's age is a factor, there have been no major health issues that would likely force him to step down. Given these factors, it seems highly unlikely that Biden would announce he will not accept the nomination before July 15, 2024. The only scenarios where this might happen would be in case of a severe health issue or an extreme political crisis, both of which are low probability events.

question.title: Will the US government end its agreement directly allowing Verisign to manage the authoritative domain name registry for the .com TLD, before August 3, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if before August 3, 2024, the US Department of Commerce (DOC) officially terminates or sunsets its Cooperative Agreement with Verisign recognizing Verisign's management of the *.com* generic top-level domain (TLD). If this does not happen, this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this event occurring, we need to consider several factors: 1. Historical context: Verisign has been managing the .com TLD since 2000, and their agreement with the US government has been renewed multiple times. This suggests a long-standing, stable relationship. 2. Current agreement: The most recent extension of the Cooperative Agreement between Verisign and the US Department of Commerce was signed in 2018, extending Verisign's management of .com until November 30, 2024. This date is beyond the resolution date of this question (August 3, 2024). 3. Importance of stability: The .com TLD is crucial for global internet infrastructure. Any change in its management would require careful planning and execution to ensure continuity and security. Abrupt changes are unlikely. 4. Lack of public discussion: As of the question's creation date (July 2, 2024), there have been no significant public discussions or announcements about ending Verisign's management of .com. Major changes to internet governance are typically preceded by extensive public debate and consultation. 5. Time frame: The question asks about a change occurring within approximately one month (from the question's creation to the resolution date). This is a very short period for such a significant change in internet governance. 6. Regulatory environment: Any change would likely involve not just the US government but also ICANN (Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers). Such multi-stakeholder decisions typically take considerable time. 7. Verisign's performance: There have been no major controversies or issues with Verisign's management of .com that would prompt an sudden termination of the agreement. Given these factors, it seems highly unlikely that the US government would abruptly end its agreement with Verisign for managing the .com TLD before August 3, 2024. The existing agreement extends beyond this date, and there are no apparent reasons or indications for an early termination. The stability of the internet ecosystem and the short timeframe make such a significant change improbable.

(b) US government ending agreement with Verisign for .com TLD management: The management of the .com TLD by Verisign is a long-standing arrangement that has been in place since 1998. However, these agreements are typically renewed or extended well in advance of their expiration to ensure stability in internet infrastructure. There have been no public indications of any plans to end this agreement prematurely. Such a significant change in internet governance would likely require extensive planning and public discussion, which we haven't seen. The probability of this occurring before August 3, 2024, is also very low. For both events to occur, we would need two highly unlikely events to happen independently and within a short timeframe. metadata.chain_of_thought:
Let's break this down into two parts and analyze each separately:

Considering both scenarios, the overall probability of either event occurring is still quite low. question.title: Will the Month-over-Month US Core CPI increase by more than 0.1% in July?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the seasonally adjusted Core CPI for July 2024 increases by more than 0.1% compared to June 2024.

The Data for resolution will be https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/CPILFESL and will use the exact (not rounded) value.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider several factors that influence the Core Consumer Price Index (CPI) and recent trends in inflation. Historical context indicates that the US has been experiencing elevated inflation rates over the past couple of years, though it has shown signs of moderating in recent months. The Core CPI, which excludes food and energy prices, is a more stable measure of underlying inflation trends. In the past year, month-over-month Core CPI increases have often exceeded 0.1%, but there have been months with lower increases as well. The Federal Reserve has been implementing aggressive interest rate hikes to combat inflation, and these actions typically take time to fully impact the economy and inflation rates. Economic conditions, such as labor market tightness, supply chain issues, and consumer demand, can also influence inflation rates. While the question specifies seasonally adjusted data, there might still be some residual seasonal effects in July. Given that the question is about July 2024, which is about a year from now, this adds significant uncertainty to the forecast. However, historical data suggests that month-over-month increases exceeding 0.1% are quite common, even in periods of more moderate inflation. Therefore, while inflation may be lower by July 2024 compared to recent peaks, a month-over-month increase of more than 0.1% in Core CPI is still quite plausible and arguably more likely than not.

question.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:
This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024.

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current polling trends: As of July 2023, Biden and Trump are relatively close in national polls, with some showing Biden ahead and others showing Trump ahead. The exact lead varies by poll. 2. Historical precedent: Polling averages tend to fluctuate over time, especially as we get closer to the election. A lead of 2-3 points is not uncommon in presidential races. 3. Time until the resolution date: The question resolves based on polling data from July 15, 2024, which is about a year from now. A lot can change in a year, including economic conditions, foreign policy situations, and potential scandals or controversies. 4. Factors affecting Trump's support: Trump's legal issues and ongoing investigations could impact his support, either positively or negatively depending on how his base and independents perceive them. 5. Factors affecting Biden's support: Biden's age and questions about his fitness for office, as well as economic conditions and his handling of various issues, could impact his support. 6. Third-party candidates: The presence of strong third-party candidates could affect the polling gap between Trump and Biden. 7. FiveThirtyEight's methodology: Their polling average tends to be quite robust and less volatile than individual polls. Given these factors, it's certainly possible that Trump could have a lead over Biden in this specific range (>2 and ≤3 points) on the specified date. However, it's a relatively narrow range, and polling leads can easily fall outside of it. The question essentially asks if Trump will be leading by more than 2 points but not more than 3 points. This is a fairly specific outcome, and while it's plausible, there are many other possible scenarios (Biden leading, Trump leading by less than 2 points, Trump leading by more than 3 points, etc.). Considering all these factors, I would estimate that there's a moderate but not high chance of this specific outcome occurring.

question.title: Will a member of the Trump family be the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024?
question.body:

 - Donald Trump
 - Donald Trump Jr.
 - Eric Trump
 - Ivanka Trump
 - Tiffany Trump
 - Melania Trump
 - Barron Trump

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of a Trump family member becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Donald Trump's prominence: As the former president and a highly influential figure in the Republican Party, Donald Trump remains the most likely candidate from his family. He has hinted at running again and maintains a strong base of supporters. 2. Legal challenges: Donald Trump faces several legal issues that could potentially impact his ability to run or his appeal to voters. However, these challenges have not significantly diminished his support among Republicans. 3. Other Trump family members: While Donald Trump Jr. and Ivanka Trump have some political presence, they lack the experience and broad support base of their father. The other family members listed have even less political involvement or public support. 4. Republican Party dynamics: There is a significant portion of the Republican Party that remains loyal to Trump and his policies. However, there are also factions within the party seeking to move beyond the Trump era. 5. Potential competitors: Other prominent Republicans, such as Ron DeSantis, Mike Pence, and Nikki Haley, have shown interest in running for the nomination, which could split the non-Trump vote. 6. Time until the nomination: With the resolution date in July 2024, there is still ample time for political landscapes to shift and new developments to occur. Given these factors, Donald Trump remains the most likely Trump family member to secure the nomination. While there are challenges and competing interests, his influence within the party and loyal supporter base give him a strong chance. The other family members have a much lower probability of becoming the nominee. Considering all these factors, I would estimate a relatively high probability of a Trump family member (primarily Donald Trump) becoming the Republican nominee.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider both parts (a) and (b) separately and then combine their probabilities. (a) Trump's lead over Biden between 2 and 3 points on July 15, 2024: As of now (2023), it's difficult to predict polling numbers for a specific date over a year in advance. However, we can consider current trends and historical data: 1. Trump and Biden are likely to be the nominees for their respective parties. 2. Recent polls have shown a close race, with leads often within a few percentage points. 3. The specific range (2-3 points) is quite narrow, making it less likely to occur on that exact date. 4. (b) A Trump family member as the Republican nominee: 1. Donald Trump is currently the front-runner for the Republican nomination. 2. Other Trump family members have not indicated serious intentions to run. 3. The Republican party has shown strong support for Donald Trump. 4. There's still time for unexpected events to occur before the nomination. Considering these points, I'd estimate the probability of a Trump family member (most likely Donald Trump himself) being the nominee at around 70-75%. Combining the probabilities: The question resolves YES if either (a) or (b) occurs. Using the probability of either event occurring formula: P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B). Assuming the events are independent (which is a reasonable assumption): P(A and B) = P(A) * P(B). Let's use the middle of our ranges: 17.5% for (a) and 72.5% for (b). P(YES) = 0.175 + 0.725 - (0.175 * 0.725) = 0.900 - 0.127 = 0.773. This calculation suggests a probability of about 77.3% that either event will occur.

Trend direction: If there's a slight trend favoring Trump, it could push his lead further into the specified range. 7. Regression to the mean: There's often a tendency for polling numbers to move back towards historical averages over time. Given these factors, it seems reasonably likely that Trump's lead will remain within the specified range. The current 2.4-point lead is already within the range, and while it could move outside this range, the short timeframe and typical polling stability suggest it's more likely to stay within or near this range. However, we must also consider the possibility of the lead falling below 2 points or rising above 4 points. Given the current 2.4-point lead, there's a higher chance of it falling below 2 than rising above 4. Considering all these factors, I would estimate there's a moderate to good chance of the lead staying within the specified range.

question.title: Will Donald Trump Jr. be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump Jr. is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Donald Trump Jr. becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political landscape: As of now, Donald Trump Sr. is the frontrunner for the 2024 Republican nomination, with other established politicians like Ron DeSantis and Nikki Haley also in the race. Donald Trump Jr. has not announced any intention to run. 2. Name recognition: While Donald Trump Jr. has a high profile due to his father's presidency, he lacks personal political experience and has never held elected office. 3. Party dynamics: The Republican Party typically favors candidates with governmental experience or a strong political track record. Trump Jr.'s lack of direct political experience would be a significant hurdle. 4. Family competition: If Donald Trump Sr. remains in the race, it's highly unlikely that his son would run against him or that the party would choose the son over the father. 5. Public perception: While popular among his father's base, Trump Jr. is a polarizing figure and may struggle to appeal to a broader Republican electorate. 6. Time until convention: With the convention still over a year away, there's time for unexpected developments, but major shifts would be needed for Trump Jr. to become a serious contender. 7. Historical precedent: It's extremely rare for a major party to nominate someone with no prior elected office experience, especially when other experienced candidates are available. Given these factors, it seems highly improbable that Donald Trump Jr. would become the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. While not impossible, it would require a series of unlikely events and a dramatic shift in the current political landscape.

question.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents?
question.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6.  One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

@/SteveSokolowski/1-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul@/SteveSokolowski/2-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul 

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error.  Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

This market will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 3% or more when both polls close.

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)).  The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03.  Otherwise, it is NO.

The polls and this question will never resolve N/A, and will remain open until the close time no matter what.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider several factors: 1. Public opinion polls: The prompt mentions that public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, while other hypothetical Democratic candidates poll ahead or within the margin of error against Trump. This suggests that Biden is a weaker candidate compared to a generic Democrat. 2. Manifold respondents vs. general public: The question asks if Manifold respondents are representative of the general public. Without specific data on Manifold's user base, we can't assume they perfectly mirror the general public. However, we can expect some correlation between Manifold respondents and broader public opinion trends. 3. The 3% threshold: The question resolves YES if Trump gains at least 3% more votes when facing Biden compared to a generic Democrat. This is a significant difference, requiring a substantial shift in voter preference. 4. Time factor: The polls close on July 6, 2024, which is relatively close to the 2024 US presidential election. This timing might lead to more informed and realistic responses from participants. 5. Potential for strategic voting: Manifold users, being familiar with prediction markets, might be more likely to vote strategically rather than purely based on preference. This could potentially skew results compared to general public polls. Given these factors, I believe there's a good chance that Trump will perform better against Biden compared to a generic Democrat among Manifold respondents, reflecting the trend seen in public opinion polls. However, the 3% threshold is quite high, which makes it less certain that the difference will be that large. The combination of Biden's apparent weakness as a candidate, the trend in public opinion polls, and the likelihood that Manifold respondents are at least somewhat representative of broader trends suggests that there's a moderate to high probability of this question resolving YES.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Donald Trump Jr. becomes the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, and (b) Trump gains at least 3% among Manifold respondents facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat?
question.body:
(a) Donald Trump Jr. will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election if he is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee. This is irrespective of who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by the delegates of the Republican National Convention.

The formula used is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)), and the difference between the polls must be >= 0.03 for a YES resolution.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To assess the probability of both events occurring, we need to consider each part separately and then combine their likelihoods.

(a) Donald Trump Jr. becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election:
This scenario is highly unlikely. Donald Trump Jr. has not announced any intention to run for president, and he lacks the political experience typically expected of presidential nominees. His father, Donald Trump Sr., is currently the frontrunner for the Republican nomination. Other experienced politicians like Ron DeSantis, Mike Pence, and Nikki Haley are also in the race or considering running. The probability of Donald Trump Jr. becoming the nominee is extremely low, perhaps around 1% or less.

(b) Trump gaining at least 3% among Manifold respondents facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat:
This part is more plausible. Donald Trump (presumably Sr.) has a dedicated base of supporters and has performed well in polls against Joe Biden. However, the specific condition of gaining at least 3% more support when facing Biden compared to a generic Democrat is quite specific. While Trump might perform better against Biden due to Biden's current approval ratings and perceived weaknesses, a 3% difference is significant. The probability of this occurring could be around 30-40%.

For both events to occur, we need to multiply these probabilities. Even if we assume the events are independent (which they likely aren't), the combined probability would be extremely low due to the improbability of Donald Trump Jr. becoming the nominee.

Probability: 0.003

This extremely low probability (0.3%) reflects the near impossibility of Donald Trump Jr. becoming the Republican nominee, combined with the specific condition of Trump Sr. gaining at least 3% more support against Biden compared to a generic Democrat.

question.title: Will either Donald Trump Jr. be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election or Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if any of the following occur: 

(a) Donald Trump Jr. is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This is determined solely by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention.

(b) The percentage of votes for Donald Trump in the first Manifold poll (with Joe Biden on the ballot) exceeds that in the second Manifold poll (with a generic Democrat on the ballot) by 3% or more when both polls close on July 6. The formula used is (Trump / (Trump + the Democrat in the question + Someone else)). The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Let's break this down into two parts: 1. Donald Trump Jr. being the Republican nominee: The likelihood of Donald Trump Jr. being the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election is extremely low. He has not shown any significant interest in running for president, and there are many other high-profile Republicans who are more likely to be nominated, including his father Donald Trump Sr., Ron DeSantis, and others. Donald Trump Jr. lacks the political experience and broad party support that would be necessary to secure the nomination. 2. Trump gaining at least 3% among Manifold respondents when facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat: This scenario is more plausible but still unlikely. The comparison between Trump vs. Biden and Trump vs. a generic Democrat could potentially show some difference, as Biden is a known quantity with both strengths and weaknesses, while a 'generic Democrat' is an abstract concept that voters might view more favorably or unfavorably depending on their personal biases. However, a 3% swing is quite significant in polling terms. Most voters tend to have fairly stable preferences, especially when it comes to such a polarizing figure as Donald Trump. The difference between Trump's performance against Biden versus a generic Democrat would likely be smaller than 3% in most cases. Additionally, the specific nature of the Manifold respondents adds another layer of uncertainty. If these respondents are particularly well-informed or have specific biases, it could affect the outcome in unpredictable ways. Given these factors, I believe the probability of either of these events occurring is low, but not negligible. The second scenario (the 3% swing) is more likely than the first (Donald Trump Jr. being nominated), but both are improbable.

- Any other categories created by ISW that indicate Russian control of the location

- Claimed Ukrainian Counteroffensives

- Reported Ukrainian Partisan Warfare

- Any other categories created by ISW that indicate Ukrainian control of the location or a lack of Russian control of the location

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Russia having control of Chasiv Yar on June 1, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current situation: As of September 2023, Chasiv Yar is under Ukrainian control. It's located in the Donetsk Oblast, close to Bakhmut, which has been a hotly contested area. 2. Strategic importance: Chasiv Yar is strategically important due to its proximity to Bakhmut and its position on higher ground. It could be a target for Russian forces if they aim to advance further west. 3. Time frame: The question asks about the situation approximately 9 months from now. This is a significant amount of time in which the conflict dynamics could change substantially. 4. Recent trends: The war has been characterized by slow, grinding advances and counteroffensives. Neither side has made rapid, large-scale territorial gains in recent months. 5. Russian objectives: Russia has shown a continued interest in fully controlling the Donetsk Oblast, which includes Chasiv Yar. 6. Ukrainian defenses: Ukraine has been fortifying its positions and has shown resilience in defending key areas. 7. International support: Continued Western support for Ukraine could influence its ability to hold territory. 8. Potential for negotiations: There's always a possibility of peace talks or ceasefires, though currently this seems unlikely. Given these factors, I believe it's more likely that Chasiv Yar will remain under Ukrainian control by June 1, 2024. However, the proximity to current frontlines and the strategic importance of the area make Russian control a significant possibility. The slow pace of territorial changes suggests that dramatic shifts are unlikely in the given timeframe. However, the unpredictable nature of war and the potential for strategic shifts or major offensives add uncertainty to this assessment.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this event occurring, we need to consider several factors: 1. Legal precedent: There have been attempts to use Section 3 of the 14th Amendment to disqualify candidates, but they have rarely been successful. The most notable recent case was the attempt to remove Marjorie Taylor Greene from the ballot in Georgia, which failed. 2. Current legal challenges: As of now, there are ongoing efforts in multiple states to remove Trump from the ballot using this argument. The most prominent cases are in Colorado and Minnesota. 3. Time frame: The resolution date is July 15, 2024, which gives ample time for legal challenges to be filed, heard, and potentially appealed through various court levels. 4. Political climate: The use of the 14th Amendment to disqualify Trump is highly controversial and politically charged, which may influence decision-making at various levels. 5. State-by-state variation: Different states may interpret and apply the law differently, increasing the chances that at least one state might take this action. 6. Trump's actions on January 6th: The events of January 6th, 2021, and Trump's role in them are central to the argument for disqualification under the 14th Amendment. 7. Potential Supreme Court involvement: Given the high-stakes nature of this issue, it's likely that any successful attempt to remove Trump from a ballot would be quickly appealed, potentially reaching the Supreme Court. 8. Public opinion and political pressure: These factors could influence how aggressively states pursue this option and how courts rule on the matter. While the legal argument for disqualification under the 14th Amendment has some merit, successfully removing Trump from even one state's ballot faces significant hurdles. The courts have generally been reluctant to interfere with ballot access, especially for major party candidates. However, the unprecedented nature of the January 6th events and Trump's actions surrounding them do provide a unique context that could lead to a different outcome. Given these factors, I believe there is a non-trivial chance that at least one state might successfully remove or block Trump from their primary ballot under these grounds by July 15, 2024. However, I still consider it more likely than not that this will not happen, given the legal and political challenges involved.

question.title:
Will the  CBOE S&P 500 3-Month Volatility Index (VXVCLS)

question.title: Will Donald Trump be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question may consider new candidates added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Donald Trump becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political landscape: As of now, Trump remains a prominent figure in the Republican Party and has a strong base of supporters. 2. Trump's intentions: He has already announced his candidacy for the 2024 election, showing his clear intention to run. 3. Polling data: Recent polls have consistently shown Trump leading other potential Republican candidates by a significant margin. 4. Fundraising ability: Trump has demonstrated a strong ability to raise funds, which is crucial for a successful campaign. 5. Name recognition: Trump has unparalleled name recognition among Republican voters, which is a significant advantage. 6. Party support: While some Republican leaders have distanced themselves from Trump, he still maintains considerable support within the party. 7. Legal challenges: Trump is facing several legal challenges, which could potentially impact his candidacy. However, these have not significantly diminished his support so far. 8. Potential competitors: While other candidates like Ron DeSantis have gained traction, they have not yet shown the ability to consistently challenge Trump's dominance in the polls. 9. Historical precedent: It's common for former presidents to become their party's nominee if they choose to run again (e.g., Grover Cleveland, Richard Nixon). 10. Time until the convention: There is still significant time until the Republican National Convention, which allows for potential shifts in the political landscape. Given these factors, Trump appears to be in a strong position to secure the Republican nomination. However, the political landscape can be unpredictable, and there are potential obstacles that could hinder his path to nomination.

question.title: Will Ted Cruz be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Ted Cruz is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Ted Cruz becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political landscape: As of now, Donald Trump and Ron DeSantis are widely considered the frontrunners for the Republican nomination. They have significantly higher polling numbers and media attention compared to Ted Cruz. 2. Cruz's previous performance: Ted Cruz was the runner-up to Donald Trump in the 2016 Republican primaries. While this shows he has some support within the party, it also indicates he was unable to secure the nomination when he had a stronger position. 3. Cruz's current standing: Cruz has not officially announced his candidacy for the 2024 election. His lack of an announcement this far into the election cycle suggests he may not be planning to run. 4. Popularity and support: Cruz's popularity within the Republican party has not significantly increased since 2016. He doesn't seem to have the same level of enthusiastic support as candidates like Trump or DeSantis. 5. Fundraising and resources: Without an official campaign, Cruz is not actively fundraising for a presidential run, putting him at a disadvantage compared to declared candidates. 6. Party dynamics: The Republican party seems to be leaning towards either a Trump-led ticket or a fresh face like DeSantis. Cruz doesn't fit neatly into either of these categories. 7. Time until convention: While there is still time for the political landscape to change before the Republican National Convention, Cruz would need a significant shift in circumstances to become the frontrunner. Given these factors, it seems highly unlikely that Ted Cruz will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. While it's not impossible, it would require a series of unexpected events and a dramatic shift in party dynamics for Cruz to secure the nomination.

question.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 3 and less than or equal to 4 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:
This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024.

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider several factors: 1. The race is generally considered tight. 2. Historical precedent: Incumbent presidents often face challenges in their re-election bids, especially if the economy is not performing well or if there are other significant issues. 3. Time until the election: The poll in question is for July 15, 2024, which is very close to the election. By this time, both campaigns will be in full swing, and public opinion will be more solidified. 4. Potential events: Between now and July 2024, many events could occur that might significantly impact the race, including debates, economic changes, international events, or scandals. 5. 538's methodology: 538 is known for its robust polling aggregation and tends to be more conservative in showing large leads. 6. Specific range: The question asks about a very narrow range (greater than 3 and less than or equal to 4 points lead for Trump). Given these factors, I believe it's unlikely but not impossible for Trump to have a lead in this specific range. Here's why: - The race is likely to remain competitive, making a lead of more than 3 points significant. - If Trump does gain a lead, it's more likely to be smaller (1-2 points) or potentially larger (5+ points) if there's a major shift in public opinion. - The specific range of 3-4 points is quite narrow, reducing the likelihood of this exact outcome. - However, if Trump does gain momentum leading up to the election, this range could represent a point where he's pulled ahead significantly but not overwhelmingly. Considering all these factors, I would estimate a relatively low probability for this specific outcome.

question.title: [Metaculus] Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democra...nomination for President?
question.body:
Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden announcing he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President before July 15, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Incumbent advantage: Historically, sitting presidents rarely decline to run for a second term unless faced with significant challenges or health issues. Biden is the incumbent, which gives him a strong position within the party. 2. Age and health concerns: Biden will be 81 at the time of the 2024 election, making him the oldest president in US history. There have been concerns about his age and mental acuity, which could potentially influence his decision. 3. Current statements and actions: As of now (July 2023), Biden has repeatedly stated his intention to run for re-election and has already launched his 2024 campaign. 4. Party support: The Democratic Party leadership has largely rallied behind Biden, and there is no significant primary challenger at this time. 5. Political landscape: The Republican field is still taking shape, and Biden may see himself as the strongest candidate to defeat potential Republican nominees. 6. Time frame: The question asks about an announcement before July 15, 2024, which is very close to the Democratic National Convention (typically held in August). It's unlikely for an incumbent to wait this long to announce they're not running. 7. Historical precedent: The last incumbent president to not seek re-election was Lyndon B. Johnson in 1968, and he announced his decision in March of that year, much earlier than the July 2024 deadline in this question. Given these factors, it seems highly unlikely that Biden would announce he's not accepting the nomination so late in the process. He has already launched his campaign, has party support, and there's no clear alternative candidate being groomed by the Democrats. While concerns about his age persist, they don't seem to have deterred him so far. The only scenario where this might happen is if there's a sudden, severe health issue or an unforeseen political crisis. However, the probability of such an event occurring and leading to this specific outcome within this timeframe is quite low.

question.title: Will there be another Democratic party presidential debate?

This leaves a relatively short window for organizing a debate, especially considering that the Democratic National Convention typically occurs in late August or early September. 5. Potential for unexpected events: While unlikely, there's always a small chance of unforeseen circumstances (e.g., health issues, scandals) that could lead to Biden stepping aside or facing a last-minute challenge. (a) Joe Biden announcing he won't accept the Democratic nomination: As of now (July 2024), Joe Biden is the incumbent president and the presumptive Democratic nominee for the 2024 election. (b) Another Democratic party presidential debate before the convention: Given that Biden is the presumptive nominee and there are no significant challengers, the Democratic National Committee (DNC) has not scheduled any debates. Debates typically occur when there's a competitive primary, which is not the case here. Even if Biden were to unexpectedly withdraw, the time between July 15 and the convention would be very short to organize a debate among potential replacements. The probability of this occurring is also very low, perhaps around 10%. For both events to occur, we need to multiply these probabilities: 0.05 * 0.10 = 0.005 or 0.5%. However, there's a slight positive correlation between these events. If Biden were to withdraw (part a), the likelihood of a debate occurring (part b) would increase significantly. This correlation might bump the joint probability up slightly.

question.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Joe Biden announces before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic nomination for President, or (b) there is another Democratic party presidential debate?
question.body:
(a) Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President? This resolves as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement that he will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. The statement must be unambiguous and conclusive, leaving no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle. If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this resolves as No.

(b) Will there be another Democratic party presidential debate? This resolves as Yes if there is a debate between potential Democratic nominees (e.g., Harris, Newsom, Whitmer, Biden, etc.) prior to the 2024 Democratic National Convention. Resolves No otherwise.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this question resolving as YES, we need to consider both parts (a) and (b) separately, as either one occurring would result in a YES resolution. (a) Joe Biden announcing he will not accept the Democratic nomination: - Biden is the incumbent president and has already announced his intention to run for re-election in 2024. - Historically, incumbent presidents rarely drop out of their re-election campaigns, especially this close to the election. - Biden's age and health have been topics of concern, but there have been no recent indications of severe health issues that would force him to withdraw. - The deadline for this announcement (July 15, 2024) is very close to the Democratic National Convention, making it unlikely for such a major change to occur at that late stage. - The probability of this occurring is quite low, estimated at around 5-10%. (b) Another Democratic party presidential debate: - With Biden as the presumptive nominee, the Democratic Party has little incentive to hold additional debates that could potentially divide the party. - The Democratic National Committee (DNC) has not announced any plans for additional debates. - However, if Biden were to withdraw or face a significant challenge, the likelihood of debates would increase dramatically. - There's also a small possibility that the party might organize a debate to showcase Biden's strengths against potential Republican opponents. - The probability of this occurring is also relatively low, estimated at around 15-20%. Combining these probabilities, we need to consider that either event could occur independently. Using the formula for the probability of at least one of two independent events occurring (P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B)), and using the higher end of our estimates: P(A or B) = 0.10 + 0.20 - (0.10 * 0.20) = 0.28 or 28%. This calculation suggests that there's roughly a 28% chance of either event occurring, which aligns with the intuition that while both scenarios are unlikely, there's a non-negligible chance of at least one happening.

question.title: Will Google DeepMind publish a report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024?
question.body: For Google DeepMind, this question resolves as **YES** if, by June 30, 2024, they publish a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models.

Potential drawbacks: Publishing such a report could expose vulnerabilities in their models, which might make DeepMind hesitant. 7. Regulatory environment: Depending on how AI regulation develops over the next year, there might be increased pressure or even requirements for such transparency. Considering these factors, I believe it's more likely than not that DeepMind will publish such a report by the given deadline. The growing emphasis on AI safety, industry trends, and potential regulatory pressures all point towards this outcome. However, there's still significant uncertainty due to DeepMind's past behavior and potential strategic considerations.

question.title: Will OpenAI's ChatGPT be generally available in the European Union on June 30, 2024?
question.body:
The question resolves as **YES** if [ChatGPT](chat.openai.com) is generally available in the EU on June 30, 2024, and **NO** otherwise.

"Generally available" here means that the default state for people in the EU is that they can access it without a VPN (possibly requiring paying for it.) If unavailable in certain EU countries (as was the case in Italy in early 2023), or unavailable to (for example) minors, this will still resolve positively, assuming at least >50% of the population can use it.

"ChatGPT" here refers to the general web interface (not the API) for interacting with GPT models. Still resolves positively if the name or website has changed, as long as OpenAI's service is substantially the same (entering queries to systems based on Large Language Models).

question.title: Will Malta qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if Malta participates in a Semi-final and is then officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. If they do not qualify, the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess Malta's chances of qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Historical performance: Malta has participated in Eurovision since 1971 and has qualified for the Grand Final in 6 out of the last 10 contests (2013-2023, excluding 2020 which was cancelled). This shows a relatively good track record. 2. Recent results: Malta qualified for the Grand Final in 2021 and 2023, but failed to qualify in 2022. Their most recent performance in 2023 saw them finish 11th in the Grand Final, which is a strong result. 3. Selection process: Malta typically uses a national final or internal selection to choose their entry. The quality of their selection process can impact their chances. 4. Competition level: The overall quality of entries from other countries can affect Malta's chances of qualifying. This is difficult to predict this far in advance. 5. Semi-final draw: The distribution of countries in each semi-final can impact qualification chances. This information is not available yet. 6. Voting patterns: Malta often receives support from countries like Italy and Australia due to diaspora voting, which can help in qualification. 7. Staging and performance: The quality of staging and live performance is crucial but cannot be assessed until closer to the event. Given Malta's recent qualification record and their strong showing in 2023, they have a good chance of qualifying again. However, Eurovision results can be unpredictable, and factors like the quality of their chosen entry and the strength of competition are unknown at this point. Considering all these factors, I believe Malta has a slightly better than even chance of qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024.

question.title: Before July 1, 2024, will the International Criminal Court issue arrest warrants for any of the listed Israeli leaders?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if before July 1, 2024, the International Criminal Court (ICC) issues a [warrant of arrest](https://www.icc-cpi.int/about/how-the-court-works) for any of the below listed Israeli cabinet members. It will resolve as **No** otherwise.

* Benjamin Netanyahu (Prime Minister)
* Yoav Gallant (Defense Minister)
* Herzi Halevi (IDF Chief of Staff)

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this event occurring, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current ICC investigations: The ICC has been investigating alleged war crimes in Palestinian territories since 2021. This ongoing investigation increases the likelihood of potential arrest warrants being issued. 2. Recent events: The ongoing Israel-Hamas conflict, which escalated in October 2023, has led to increased international scrutiny of Israel's actions in Gaza. This heightened attention could potentially accelerate the ICC's investigation process. 3. Political pressure: There has been growing international pressure on Israel regarding its conduct in the conflict, which could influence the ICC's decision-making process. 4. Precedent: The ICC has previously issued arrest warrants for sitting heads of state and government officials in other cases, demonstrating its willingness to take such actions. 5. Time frame: The question allows for a relatively long period (until July 1, 2024) for the ICC to issue arrest warrants, which increases the likelihood of this occurring. 6. Specific individuals named: The question focuses on high-ranking Israeli officials, including the Prime Minister, Defense Minister, and IDF Chief of Staff, who are directly involved in decision-making regarding military operations. 7. ICC's jurisdiction: While Israel is not a party to the Rome Statute, the ICC claims jurisdiction over alleged crimes committed in Palestinian territories, which Israel contests. 8. Political implications: Issuing arrest warrants for top Israeli officials would be a highly controversial move with significant diplomatic repercussions, which might make the ICC hesitant. 9. Considering these factors, there is a significant possibility that the ICC could issue arrest warrants for one or more of the named Israeli leaders before July 1, 2024. However, the political sensitivity of such an action and the typically slow pace of ICC proceedings somewhat reduce this likelihood.

question.title: Will a terrorist act occur in metropolitan France during the 2024 Summer Olympics?
question.body:

An event will be considered a 'terrorist attack' if it is described as such by any agency of the State of France, or by the French President, Prime Minister, or a member of the Council of Ministers.

Considering these factors, there is a significant risk of a terrorist act occurring during the Olympics. question.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

Potential events: The period between July 5 and July 15 is relatively short, reducing the likelihood of major campaign events or external factors significantly shifting polls. 5. Margin of error: Most polls have a margin of error of around 3 percentage points, which means small fluctuations are common and not necessarily indicative of real changes in voter preference. 6. Regression to the mean: If the current 2.4 point lead is seen as somewhat of an outlier, there might be a slight tendency for the numbers to move back towards a longer-term average. 7. Summer polling: July is still relatively early in the general election campaign, and summer polls are often less predictive of final outcomes. question.title: Will Joe Biden have an in-person interview/conversation on camera for 45+ minutes, before the end of July 2024?
question.body:
The most recent qualifying interview was Biden's appearance on The Howard Stern Show in April, when Biden answered questions for ~70 minutes. 

If Biden appears in another such in-person interview for at least 45 minutes, this market resolves YES. If no qualifying interview is released before market close at the end of July, this market resolves NO. 

This market does not include press conferences, speeches, rallies, fundraisers, town halls, etc. It can include appearances on a podcast or late night show, or an interview edited into a show like 60 minutes. However, there must be at least 45 minutes of new footage of Biden being interviewed in-person for such appearances to count. A 50 minute video might only feature 20 minutes of video of Biden being interviewed, and so would not count.

For context, Biden's interview with Stephanopoulos in July, his appearance on Jimmy Fallon in February, and his past appearances on 60 minutes have each had less than 30 minutes of video footage of Biden being interviewed. 

You can find a list of Biden's interviews and their transcripts here.

Long-form interviews can be an effective way to communicate his message and connect with the electorate. 4. question.title: Will Chris Christie be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Chris Christie is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Chris Christie becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political landscape: As of now, Donald Trump and Ron DeSantis are widely considered the frontrunners for the Republican nomination. Christie is not currently seen as a top-tier candidate. 2. Christie's past performance: He ran for the Republican nomination in 2016 but dropped out early after poor showings in Iowa and New Hampshire. 3. Christie's relationship with Trump: Christie has become increasingly critical of Trump, which may alienate a significant portion of the Republican base that still supports the former president. 4. Lack of current momentum: Christie has not yet officially announced his candidacy, and there isn't significant buzz or grassroots support for his potential run. 5. Crowded field: The Republican primary is likely to be crowded, which could further dilute Christie's chances of standing out. 6. Time until the convention: While there is still time for the political landscape to change dramatically before the 2024 convention, Christie would need to overcome significant obstacles to become a frontrunner. 7. Christie's appeal: He may attract some moderate Republicans and independents, but his brash style and past controversies (e.g., Bridgegate) could limit his broader appeal. 8. Fundraising challenges: As a non-frontrunner, Christie may struggle to raise the necessary funds to mount a competitive national campaign. Given these factors, it seems highly unlikely that Chris Christie will become the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. While not impossible, it would require a significant shift in the current political dynamics and a series of unexpected events that would propel Christie to the forefront of the race.

question.title: Will 538 Project Biden as the favorite on Friday?
question.body:
This market will resolve to “Yes” if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. This market will resolve to “No” if Donald Trump has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this market will resolve 50-50.

The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2024-election-forecast/, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market.

This market will resolve according to the datapoints for July 19 as soon as datapoints for July 20 become available. This market may not resolve until the July 20 datapoints are available. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, this market will resolve according to the nearest previous figures to July 19.

Please note the resolution refers to the odds of each candidate winning as a number out of 100 reported to the 1 digit mark (eg. "Trump 57 times out of 100"). The listed number of simulations out of 1,000 won by each candidate will NOT be considered.

question.title: Will Donald Trump testify at the hush money trial?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions) report Donald Trump has testified, whether in person or remotely, at the [trial](https://iapps.courts.state.ny.us/webcrim_attorney/Detail?which=case&docketNumber=q23XFOwZRDQ1d4LrNRdw2clqCMt/CzUoG/kRII/7Nmg=&countyId=K4i18rFVPQh5HTQ/kUoO3Q==&docketId=3Y4iKU5oHM75AtDme2cPhw==&docketDseq=T/O1YN_PLUS_BG65HkOeqEnpAkw==&defendantName=TRUMP,+DONALD&court=New+York+Supreme+Criminal+Court&courtType=U&recordType=U&recordNum=) concerning the so-called "hush money" payments to Stormy Daniels.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Donald Trump testifying at the hush money trial, we need to consider several factors: 1. Legal strategy: Trump's legal team will likely advise him on whether testifying is in his best interest. Generally, defendants are not required to testify, and many choose not to do so to avoid potential self-incrimination. 2. Trump's personality: He has a history of being outspoken and desiring to defend himself publicly. This might increase the likelihood of him wanting to testify. 3. Precedent: In previous legal matters, Trump has often given depositions but has been less inclined to testify in open court. 4. Potential risks: Testifying could expose Trump to cross-examination, which might be risky given his tendency to make spontaneous statements. 5. Public perception: Trump might view testifying as an opportunity to speak directly to his supporters and the public, which could be appealing to him. 6. Case strength: If Trump's legal team believes the prosecution's case is weak, they might advise against testifying to avoid unnecessary risks. 7. Time until trial: The trial is set for March 25, 2024, which gives time for strategies to change and for Trump to make decisions closer to the date. 8. Political considerations: As the trial will occur during the 2024 presidential campaign (assuming Trump runs), he might see testifying as a political opportunity or risk. Given these factors, it seems that while there are reasons Trump might want to testify, the legal risks and typical defense strategies suggest it's less likely than not. However, Trump's unpredictable nature and desire for public attention do increase the probability somewhat.

question.title: Will Greens–EFA hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if the Greens–EFA political group holds the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections and as **No** for all other outcomes. If two groups are tied for seats, both sub-questions will resolve as **Yes**.

This question resolves on the basis of [official statements by the European Parliament](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en) or credible media reports.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of the Greens–EFA holding the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current representation: As of 2023, the Greens–EFA group holds 72 out of 705 seats in the European Parliament, making them the 4th largest group. This is significantly behind the largest groups like the European People's Party (EPP) and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D). 2. Historical performance: The Greens–EFA has never been the largest group in the European Parliament. Their best performance was in the 2019 elections when they gained seats but still remained the 4th largest group. 3. Political trends: While environmental issues have gained prominence in recent years, this hasn't translated into a dominant position for Green parties across Europe. Many traditional center-right and center-left parties have also adopted more environmentally friendly policies, potentially limiting the Greens' growth. 4. National politics: The performance of Green parties varies significantly across EU member states. While they have seen some success in countries like Germany and France, they remain relatively minor parties in many other EU countries. 5. Electoral system: The European Parliament uses proportional representation, which tends to favor larger, established parties and makes it difficult for smaller parties to become dominant. 6. Time until the election: The election is still about a year away, which means there's time for political landscapes to shift. However, such a dramatic shift as would be required for the Greens–EFA to become the largest group seems unlikely. 7. Competition: Other major groups like the EPP, S&D, and Renew Europe are likely to maintain strong positions, making it very challenging for the Greens–EFA to overtake them all. Given these factors, it seems highly unlikely that the Greens–EFA will hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections. While they may potentially gain some seats, overtaking all other major groups would require an unprecedented and currently unforeseen political shift across Europe.

question.title: Will GUE/NGL hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if GUE/NGL holds the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections and as **No** for all other political groups. If two groups are tied for seats, both will resolve as **Yes**.

This question resolves on the basis of [official statements by the European Parliament](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en) or credible media reports.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of GUE/NGL holding the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current standing: As of the 2019 European Parliament elections, GUE/NGL (European United Left–Nordic Green Left) holds 39 out of 705 seats, making it one of the smaller groups in the European Parliament. 2. Historical performance: GUE/NGL has never been the largest group in the European Parliament since its formation in 1989. It has consistently been one of the smaller groups. 3. Political trends: There has been a rise in populist and far-right parties across Europe in recent years, which doesn't typically align with GUE/NGL's left-wing ideology. 4. Largest groups: The European People's Party (EPP) and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D) have traditionally been the largest groups in the European Parliament. In the 2019 elections, they held 182 and 154 seats respectively. 5. Voter sentiment: There's no significant indication of a massive shift in voter sentiment across Europe that would suggest a dramatic increase in support for far-left parties represented by GUE/NGL. 6. Coalition building: Even if GUE/NGL were to gain seats, it would need to more than quadruple its current seat count to have a chance at being the largest group, which is highly improbable. 7. Political landscape: The fragmentation of the political landscape in many European countries might lead to a more diverse parliament, but it's unlikely to significantly benefit GUE/NGL to the extent required. Given these factors, it appears extremely unlikely that GUE/NGL will hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections. The group would need to overcome significant historical, political, and numerical barriers to achieve this outcome. While political landscapes can change, there's no evidence suggesting such a dramatic shift is likely to occur by 2024.

question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if both the Greens–EFA political group and the GUE/NGL political group hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections. If either group does not hold the most seats, this question will resolve as **No**. If the Greens–EFA and GUE/NGL are tied for the most seats, this question resolves as **Yes**. This question resolves on the basis of [official statements by the European Parliament](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en) or credible media reports.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of both the Greens–EFA and GUE/NGL holding the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current seat distribution: As of 2023, neither the Greens–EFA nor GUE/NGL hold the most seats in the European Parliament. The European People's Party (EPP) and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D) are currently the largest groups. 2. Historical performance: Both the Greens–EFA and GUE/NGL have traditionally been smaller groups in the European Parliament, rarely coming close to being the largest groups. 3. Political trends: While environmental issues and left-wing policies have gained some traction in recent years, it's unlikely that this trend is strong enough to propel both groups to the top positions simultaneously. 4. Fragmentation of the left: The existence of multiple left-leaning groups (including S&D, Greens–EFA, and GUE/NGL) tends to split the vote, making it less likely for two left-wing groups to dominate. 5. Rise of right-wing populism: In recent years, right-wing populist parties have gained ground in many European countries, which could potentially take votes away from left-leaning groups. 6. Voter turnout and preferences: European Parliament elections often see lower turnout than national elections, and voters may use them to express protest votes, which can lead to unpredictable results. However, this unpredictability is unlikely to benefit both groups simultaneously to such a large extent. 7. The requirement for both groups to hold the most seats: Even if one of these groups were to make significant gains, the probability of both groups simultaneously becoming the largest is extremely low. Given these factors, it is highly improbable that both the Greens–EFA and GUE/NGL will hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections. While surprises can happen in politics, the scenario described would require an unprecedented and highly unlikely shift in European political dynamics.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this outcome, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current seat distribution: As of 2023, the Greens–EFA holds 72 seats, while GUE/NGL holds 38 seats in the European Parliament. This is significantly fewer than the largest groups like EPP (176 seats) or S&D (145 seats). 2. Historical performance: Neither the Greens–EFA nor GUE/NGL has ever been the largest group in the European Parliament. They typically represent smaller, more niche political ideologies compared to the mainstream center-right and center-left parties. 3. This makes it unlikely for either the Greens or the far-left to become the largest group. 5. Given these factors, it appears highly unlikely that either the Greens–EFA or GUE/NGL will hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections.
